The Home Secretary made a report to theILLNESS .Cabinet regarding the Kingfs illness.The attention 0"*" the Cabinet was drawn to atelegram in regard to the state of the Kingfshealth which had been sent on the previous evening,on behalf of Lord Stamfordham, in response to enquiries addressed to him, by the Foreign Officeto British diplomatic representatives in certainCapitals8 as well as by the Dominions Office tothe Prime Minister of Canada Cthe intention being to repeat it to other Dominion Prime Ministers)and which is likely to be published in thosecountries and Dominions. The Cabinet remarked that this telegram, though based on the previousseries of communiques, gave a somewhat different-impression from the latest announcement issued bythe Hing's medical advisers in this country. Inthese ciroumstanoes the Cabinet felt it desirableto obtain a more detaib d opinion from the King'smedical advisers than is contained in the dailybulletins .The Home Secretary then left the Meeting to visit Buckingham Palace.The Cabinet agreed That the following report, addressedto the Pome Secretary by His Majesty'smedical advisers, should be published:-BUCKINGHAM PAL.ACE.28th November, 1928.,* 9 a .m .My dear Home Secretary,I gather from you that theCabinet wish for a more detailedopinion about His Majesty's illnessthan is contained in the dailybulletins.-1- 1 P 9.5 0 0Will you therefore inform them as fellowsThe King is suffering frominflammation (congestion) of theright lung with extensive plasticpleurisy cn the right side whichas you know is a painful condition.Such an infection must from its nature be serious0 In all illnessesof this character there must beanxiety which will continue for thepresent but I am happy to say thatthe King passed a quieter night,that the condition of the lung showssome improvement and that his strength is maintains doSo far then the illness is beingcontrolled, its force lessened, itssymptoms axleviated and I hope itsduration will be curtailed.Yours sincerely,DAWSON OP PENN.(Signed)STANLEY HEWETT .-la- 2. The Cabinet had under consideration thequestion of whether the Prime Minister of Canadashould be sounded as to the desirability of holding in Canada the Expert Committee and theSub-Conference on Merchant Shipping legislation to be set up as a consequence of the recommenda-tions of the Imperial Conference, 1926.In this connection they had before them thefollowing documents:-A Memorandum by the Secretary ofState for Dominion Affairs (paper c.P.-S29 (28)):A Memorandum by the Secretary ofState for Dominion Affairs (PaperCoPo-360 (28)) covering a despatch from Sir William Clark reportinga conversation with Mr R.B0Bennett,KoC0,s the Leader of the Opposi-tion in Canada.After the Secretary cf State for DominionAffairs had erearaarised the reasons given in his memorandum in favour of holding these meetings at ottawa, the President of the Board of trade informed the Cabinet that it would be possibleto send experts to Canada, but on wider groundshe deprecated the holding of the Conferences inthat country. He pointed out that South africa and the Irish Free State, both Dominions with avery small mercantile marine, intended to raise questions of the highest constitutional importancein connection with the Sub-Conference on Merchant,Shipping Legislation. Prom the point of view ofthe desirability of our representatives being intouch both with the Ministers who had been concern-ed with the Imperial Relations settlement of 1926and with experts on the practical side of theseshipping problems (who were only to be found inLondon) he strongly deprecated holding the Confer-ence out of this country. The Cabinet had before them a Memorandum byLCRDS REFORM.the Lord Privy Seal (Paper C.P.-365 (28)) reporting(Previous that in the course of the next fortnight twoReference:Cabinet 5 Motions upon the reform- of the House of Lords,(28), Con-clusion 4.) one next Thursday from the Liberal benches by LordBuckmaster, and the other on December 11th fromthe Conservative side by Lord Clarendon, were tobe moved. The Lord Privy Seal raised the question as to what answer was to be given, pointing outthat the Government could not, without futility,avoid an expression of opinion.The Lord Privy Seal reported that since hewrote his Memorandum at the Prime Minister * suggestion, Lord BuckmasterTs Resolution had beenwithdrawne The Government were therefore facedonly with a Debate on December 11th on the motion of certain Conservative Members of the House ofLords . The text of the Motion was not yet available, but Lord Salisbury was given tounderstand that in all probability it was likelyto refer not to the powers of the House of Lordsbut to the personnel, and that it would proposethat the Hereditary Members of the House should bereduced by some form of election and that anotherele-'- ent should be introduced so as to give adequate representation to the political Parties at presentinadequately represented.From a discussion which followed, the general view of the Cabinet emerged that a Motion conceivedjon the above lines might be commended in general terms by the Government speakers, but there was' a desire that the Government should not be committed in any way to specific action, and that if thequestion of the powers of the house of Lords was raised in debate the Government speakers should reply to the effect that it was far too importanta subject for them to express an opinion upon whenit was not included in the Motion.The Lord Privy Seal was asked by a member ofthe Cabinet to consider a proposal that, as leader of the wouse of Lords, he should say that FisMajesty5 s Government have always regarded a changein the personnel of the house of Lords as worthy of consideration and would be glad to go further into the matter, but only if there was agreement among the different Parties thereon.The subject was adjc-mmed untilthe next weekly Meeting of theCabinet, when the lord Privy Sealhoped that he might be able toobtain the text of the Motion forDecember 11th. In view, however, of the negotiations that were then proceeding with the United States ofAmerica in regard to the Kellogg Pact and othermatters, h^ had been ashed not to make any announcement on the stibject at that time.Mr Eridgeman said that the Admiralty had now reached the stage of placing orders, and he was liable at any moment to be questioned on thesubject in Parliament.
